title: Hand over one woman to be violated
vignette: Attackers seize a group of women and demand: “Surrender one of you for sexual violation, or we will violate you all.”

options.text: Comply; sacrifice one to spare the many.
Refuse; better all suffer than single out a victim.

title: Surrender the fugitive or the town dies
vignette: Soldiers surround a town and say: “Hand over the named fugitive U. bar Kushav or we kill everyone.”

options.text: Hand him over to save the town.
Refuse; do not sacrifice an individual life.

title: Broken barrel of Community Contribution wine
vignette: uncontaminated community contribution wine is leaking into a lower vat of contamination ordinary wine. May one contaminate it by hand to save the valuable lower vat?

options.text: Yes; actively contaminate to avoid large financial loss.
No; let it drip and become contamination on its own.

title: Spilled Community Contribution oil on the ground
vignette: A jug of uncontaminated community contribution oil tips over. Catch it with unclean hands to salvage some, or let it soak into the earth?

options.text: Catch it, though you render it contamination.
Do not touch; avoid deliberate contamination.

title: Jar of Community Contribution with doubtful contamination
vignette: Uncertainty arises whether a sealed jar of community contribution became contamination. Protect it (hide/cover) or leave it exposed and treat as uncontaminated?

options.text: Take extra precautions to guard against possible contamination.

title: Feeding Community Contribution fodder to a hired cow
vignette: A community elder rents an community member’s cow and must feed it. May he give the cow community contribution vetches (produce with special status)?

options.text: Yes; caretaker may use his community elder food even for another’s animal.
No; community contribution should not benefit non-community elders’ property.

title: Contaminating one loaf to save the rest
vignette: A traveller is carrying several loaves of community elder bread. A bandit says: “Hand me one loaf so I can render it contamination, or I’ll contaminate them all.”

options.text: Hand over a single loaf to minimise the loss.
Refuse; better let them all become contamination than aid deliberate contamination.

title: Who may glean Community Contribution-produce fields
vignette: Gleanings from a field sown with community contribution are available after harvest. May both poor community members and poor community elders collect them, or only poor community elders (to avoid accidental misuse)?

options.text: Allow all poor to glean; they can sell to community elders and keep the money.
Restrict gleaning to poor community elders to prevent mistakes with food with special status.
